title: NFL Receiver Antonio Brown Accused of Rape in Lawsuit
text:
New England Patriots receiver Antonio Brown, who recently joined the Super Bowl champions after two other teams, has been accused of raping a woman, according to a lawsuit she filed Tuesday.

The civil lawsuit, filed in the Southern District of Florida, alleges that Mr. Brown, 31 years old, assaulted the woman, Britney Taylor, on multiple occasions in 2017 and 2018, including one alleged incident in which she says he cornered her, pulled her onto a bed and forced himself on her with “great violence.”

Ms. Taylor, who is 28, said in the suit that she met Mr. Brown when they attended Central Michigan University together. She later became his trainer, which is when he began assaulting her, according to the suit.

Mr. Brown denies “each and every allegation” in the lawsuit, according to a statement from his lawyer, Darren Heitner. The statement said Mr. Brown and Ms. Taylor had sex but that “any sexual interaction” between them was consensual, including the night in which she accuses him of raping her. Mr. Brown’s lawyer described the lawsuit against his client as a “money grab.” The Patriots, who just days ago agreed to a deal with the star receiver, didn't immediately respond to requests for comment. The suit alleges various incidents of misconduct by Mr. Brown over two years. In one alleged incident, in June 2017, Mr. Brown exposed himself and kissed Taylor without her consent, the suit alleges. After the alleged incidents, Ms. Taylor stopped working for Mr. Brown, according to the suit. But months later, she says, Mr. Brown persuaded her to resume working with him, after which he raped her, the suit alleges. In May 2018, it says, Mr. Brown physically overpowered her and disregarded her pleas for him to stop and forcibly penetrated her. “As a rape victim of Antonio Brown, deciding to speak out has been an incredibly difficult decision,” Ms. Taylor said in a statement through her lawyers. It wasn’t immediately clear whether any of her accusations against Mr. Brown were reported to police. Ms. Taylor said she would cooperate with the National Football League. The accusation, earlier reported by the New York Times, comes after a turbulent off-season for Brown, one of football’s most talented players. When Mr. Brown signed with the Patriots, the deal marked his third team in less than a year. He asked to leave Pittsburgh at the end of last season, and the Steelers traded him to the Oakland Raiders. After a series of disagreements with the Raiders, he demanded his release, which was granted before he ever played a game for the team. That release potentially cost Mr. Brown a great deal of money, but it didn’t take him long to agree to terms with the Patriots on a new deal with the reigning Super Bowl champions. He has yet to suit up for the Patriots, and his first opportunity would have been next weekend, though it is unclear if he will now be permitted to do so.
